catalyst.source: The results of control experiments confirmed that no product for CO 2 reduction was detected in the absence of either irradiation or photocatalyst and the photocatalytic activity was never discovered using the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O photocatalysts.
catalyst.context: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement of the asprepared samples were conducted to investigate the chemical composition.Fig. 3a showed the Cu 2p spectra of Cu 2 O and WO 3 / Cu 2 O-150 composite, the peaks at 932.4 and 952.2 eV were corresponding to the Cu(I) characteristic peaks 23.Yet, the Cu(II) peak was discovered at at 933.6 eV, which may be due to the oxidation of Cu(I) surface in air.Moreover, the weak and broad satellite peaks around 943.0 eV also appeared 24,25.The binding energies of W4f and Cu2p in pure materials slightly shifted as compared with those in WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150, suggesting a chemical interaction between Cu 2 O and WO 3 26. The optical properties of the as-prepared samples were The photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction using the asprepared samples was investigated under visible-light illumination.The results of control experiments confirmed that no product for CO 2 reduction was detected in the absence of either irradiation or photocatalyst and the photocatalytic activity was never discovered using the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O photocatalysts.WO 3 and Cu 2 O exhibited no or negligible activities for CO 2 reduction, which were mainly attributed to the weak electron reduction ability of WO 3 and rapid recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs in Cu 2 O, respectively.As shown in Fig. 5, the WO 3 / Cu 2 O composite samples all achieved the conversion from CO 2 to value-added products and variety kinds of products was found and included the H 2 , O 2 , CO and CH 4 molecules, which was the reason that water-splitting reaction competed with the CO 2 reduction.According to 13 C labelled isotropic experiment (Fig. S3), the CO and CH 4 products were generated from CO 2 gas reactant in this study.With the Cu 2 O content of composites increasing, the yields of CO and CH 4 products were gradually promoted and the H 2 yield decreased and the percentage of CH 4 yield in catalytic productions also increased (Table S1).The CO, CH 4 Apart from the composition of photocatalyst, the photocatalytic activity was usually influenced on the external conditions, such as the catalytic temperature, total pressure, molar ratio between CO 2 and H 2 O 2,3,30.The results about influence of reaction temperature on the photocatalytic activity were showed in Fig. S4.The photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction was not observably sensitive to the catalytic temperature from 5 C to 60 C. The temperature was hence set to 40 C in this experiment.Fig. 6 showed CO, CH 4 and O 2 yields of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with different molar ratio between CO 2 and H 2 O in the constant total pressure of 0.05 MPa for the optimized catalyst after 7 h irradiation.The CH 4 yield increases and the CO yield never exhibited the distinct change with CO 2 /H 2 O molar ratio increasing.But decrease beyond 0.025 ratio, all products yields showed the evident decrease, which may be explained by the fact that the H 2 O molecules are readily accessible to the catalyst surface with hydroxyl 28.However, too much H 2 O molecules may retard the redox reaction occurring at the surface of the catalyst.The influence of the photocatalytic activity on the catalytic pressure was investigated. Under optimized catalytic conduction, the photocatalytic activity of WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 sample for CO 2 reduction was studied under visible-light illumination.As shown in Fig. 7, all product yields exhibited the escalation, prolonging the illumination time.Only small quantity of H 2 , as reduced production of water splitting, could be discovered after 12 h irradiation, which implied that the WO 3 / Cu 2 O sample has the property of the selected catalysis.The yields of CO, CH 4 , H 2 and O 2 products could attain 7.04, 8.42, 0.80 and 16.27 mmol after 24 h visible-light illumination.As shown in Fig. S5, the experimental yield of O 2 was lower than the theoretical value, and the difference between them increased with prolonging illumination time.It was possible that Cu(I) oxidation consumed the photoinduced holes and H 2 O 2 molecules were generated 28,31. In the practical applications of the long-term use, the reproducibility and durability of photocatalyst never be ignored.In the cycling tests (Fig. 8), the representative WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 photocatalyst was recycled for the four times.In 4 cycling, the CO, CH 4 , H 2 and O 2 yields for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction still reached 4.76, 7.07, 0.40 and 11.84 mmol, respectively.It was revealed that the catalyst could maintain considerable activity.The XRD patterns and XPS spectra, which showed no apparent deterioration as compared to the fresh catalyst, supplied a powerful support for its stability (Figs.S6 andS7). Photocatalytic mechanism of the WO 3 /Cu 2 O samples for CO 2 reduction was studied, according to the experimental results.In this study, the Cu 2 O phase was deposited on the surface of WO 3 , and then the contact between the two phases would form a p-n junction.Under light illumination, the electrons of each semiconductor component in composites could be induced to CB and the holes were accordingly formed in VB.The photoinduced electron-hole separation process in heterojuntion can be schematically depicted in Fig. 9a andb.Since the products of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction never was discovered using the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O sample, the reduction capacity of electrons in the CB of WO 3 would not realize the transform from CO 2 to CO and CH 4 .Based on the band energy alignment of heterojunction, the CB potential of WO 3 (0.06 V vs. NHE) was distinctly more positive than the standard redox potential E (CO2/CO) (A0.53 V vs. NHE) and E (CO2/ CH4) (A0.24 V vs. NHE) and hence, the electron in CB of WO 3 could not reduce CO 2 to CO or CH 4 in thermodynamics 1,2.The similar results was showed that the capacity of hole in the VB of Cu 2 O can not be able to oxidize water 2.According to the enhanced photocatalytic activity, the separation mode of photogenerated electron-hole maybe be followed by the Z-scheme mechanism (Fig. 9b).If so, the photoinduced electrons transfer directly from the CB of WO 3 to the VB of Cu 2 O and recombine with the holes.Hence, the abundant electrons was separated and accumulated in CB of Cu 2 O and the cumulative holes would stay at VB of WO 3 .Based on the band structure of WO 3 and Cu 2 O, the accumulated electron and hole would exhibit the strong reducing and oxidizing ability, which could accomplish CO 2 reduction and H 2 O oxidation, respectively.Hence, the WO 3 /Cu 2 O system may be a type of direct Z-scheme photocatalyst under our experimental conditions. In order to gain more demonstration for the separation of photoinduced electron-hole, transient photocurrent responses of pure and composite samples were recorded in on-off irradiation cycles.Fig. 10 presented the I-t curves for the WO 3 , pure Cu 2 O and WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 samples.The photocurrent response of the WO 3 / Cu 2 O-150 composites can fast increase under each irradiation and quickly decrease in the dark, which was in accordance with an observation for Cu 2 O sample.Moreover, the photocurrent of the composite was least 2.5 times higher than that of pure sample, which indicated that the heterojuntion in composite brought the enhancement of electron-hole separation efficiency and the reduction of recombination rate 29,32. Based on the above analyses, it was clear that the WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites were typical direct Z-scheme photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction under visible-light irradiation.Nevertheless, the exact mechanism of CO 2 photoreduction was still not clear due to many questions to be unraveled, including the exact reaction pathway, the effects of the reaction conditions, as well as the selectivity of the entire process.Therefore, more experiments should be further made to understand the underlying mechanism of the activity and selectivity of the CO 2 photoreduction.

catalyst.source: A series of WO 3 /Cu 2 O photocatalysts were synthesized by a solvothermal-electrodeposition method.
catalyst.context: A series of WO 3 /Cu 2 O photocatalysts were synthesized by a solvothermal-electrodeposition method.With the Cu 2 O content increasing, the WO 3 /Cu 2 O composite with 2D/3D morphology was formed and brought the enhanced photocatalytic performance for CO 2 reduction under visible light.The CO, CH 4 and H 2 yields for CO 2 reduction under water vapor could attain 7.04, 8.42 and 0.80 mmol after 24 h irradiation using the 2D/3D WO 3 /Cu 2 O photocatalyst.Besides, the effect of light intensity, water pressure and temperature on the photocatalytic activity was also investigated.The photocatalytic activity was not sensitive to the temperature in the experimental range.The mechanism of the improved photocatalytic activity was proposed and the photoreduction of CO 2 to CO and CH 4 in mixture atmosphere of CO 2 and water vapor was inferred.The enhanced photoactivity of WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites was ascribed to the efficient separation of the photoinduced electronhole pairs induced by Z-scheme transfer.In summary, the present research was expected to be useful in developing Z-scheme photocatalysts and provide some meaningful information for deep understanding how the photogenerated electrons transfer across the solid-solid contact interface. Structure, morphology and compositon XRD characterization was performed to investigate the crystal structure of single-component Cu 2 O and WO 3 samples and WO 3 / Cu 2 O composites with different deposition times.As shown in Fig. 1, the diffraction peaks at 36.4 and 42.3 were assigned to the (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) facets of cubic Cu 2 O (JCPDS No. 01-078-2076), and the peak intensities of Cu 2 O increased gradually with the extension of electro-deposition time.It indicated that the (1 1 1) facets of higher activity over cubic Cu 2 O was exhibited in the as-prepared WO 3 /Cu 2 O composite, leading to the enhanced performance for CO 2 reduction 11.Besides the peaks originated from Cu 2 O and FTO substrate, all the other diffraction peaks obtained from WO 3 /Cu 2 O were well indexed to hexagonal WO 3 (JCPDS No. 00-033-1387).The results indicated that Cu 2 O was successfully electrodeposited onto WO 3 platform, confirming the formation of WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites. Fig. 1.XRD patterns of the Cu 2 O, h-WO 3 and WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites. calculated by DRS measurement (Fig.4).The light-absorption edge of pure WO 3 samples could reach about 440 nm and the absorbinglight capacity was increased in the range of 500e800 nm.It was the reason that the surface defect of WO 3 sample was existed.The Cu 2 O and WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites exhibited the strong absorption in visible light range.The composites were possible to become the visible-light-driven photocatalyst.The band gaps (E g ) of the obtained photocatalysts were determined by the plots of (ahn) n versus band energy(Fig.S1).The value of n equals to 0.5 and 2 for WO 3 with an indirect band transition and Cu 2 O with a direct band transition, respectively10,27.The calculated E g values for WO 3 and Cu 2 O were 2.83 and 2.05 eV, agreeing well with the literature reports.Additionally, the VB-XPS spectra of the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O samples were presented in Fig.S2.The valance band maximums (E VB ) of WO 3 and Cu 2 O were measured to be located at 2.89 and 0.91 eV, respectively.Combining with the E g value, the condition band maximums (E CBM ) of WO 3 could be calculated to be 0.06 eV, while the E CB of Cu 2 O could reach A1.14 eV, agreeing with the previously reported values28,29.Hence, a type II (staggered) band alignment band structure of the WO 3 /Cu 2 O composite photocatalyst was successfully formed. and O 2 yields could reach 3.84, 2.22 and 6.11 mmol, respectively.Yet, the overmuch Cu 2 O brought the decline of CO 2 reduction yield.It was the reason that the exposed surface of WO 3 drop with the loaded Cu 2 O raise, leading to the decline for active site of H 2 O oxidation.The WO 3 / Cu 2 O heterojunction could accomplish the photocatalysis for CO 2 reduction and H 2 O oxidation. Fig. 3. XPS spectra of the pure and composite samples(W 4f (a) and Cu 2p (b)). Fig. 4. Optical absorption spectra of the h-WO 3 , Cu 2 O and WO 3 /Cu 2 O samples. Fig. 5. Photocatalytic activity of CO 2 reduction after 7 h visible light irradiation using different samples(A.WO 3 /Cu 2 O-50, B. WO 3 /Cu 2 O-100, C. WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150, D. WO 3 / Cu 2 O-200, E. WO 3 /Cu 2 O-250 and FWO 3 /Cu 2 O-350). Fig. 6.Photocatalytic performance of CO 2 reduction with different ratio of H 2 O/CO 2 . Fig. 7. Product yields for CO 2 reduction over WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 with H 2 O/CO 2 ratio of 0.025 at 40 C under irradiation for different time. Fig. 8. Photocatalytic activity of CO 2 reduction using WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 sample after 18 h illumination in cycling experiment. light source.source: With the present of Cu 2 O octahedrons on the WO 3 flake, the CH 4 product appeared and the maximal CO and CH 4 yields could attain 7.04 and 8.42 mmol after 24 h of visible-light irradiation.
light source.context: The 3D/2D architecture of Cu 2 O octahedrons/WO 3 nanoflake were built on the substrate surface of fluorine-doped stannic oxide.The composite photocatalyst was composed by Cubic phase Cu 2 O/hexagonal phase WO 3 .The photoreduction CO 2 activities of the composite samples were studied in the presence of water vapor.The yields and selection of CO and CH 4 products were changed with deposited Cu 2 O.With the present of Cu 2 O octahedrons on the WO 3 flake, the CH 4 product appeared and the maximal CO and CH 4 yields could attain 7.04 and 8.42 mmol after 24 h of visible-light irradiation.The photostability and photoactivity of Cu 2 O for CO 2 reduction were enhanced by the building of the WO 3 / Cu 2 O heterojuntion.The Type II band alignment for WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojuntion was characterized by UV eVis reflectance and value-band X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy and the Z-scheme mechanism of photoinduced electron-hole was further proposed.This study could offer a new clue for designing Cu 2 Obased heterojunction photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction.

lamp.source: The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction test in H 2 O vapor was measured in a reactor with a top quartz window under A 300 W Xenon arc lamp (PLS-HXF 300, Beijing China Education Au-light Co. Ltd.) with a UV cutoff filter (l 400 nm).
lamp.context: Hexagonal WO 3 nanosheets were synthesized according to our previous study 21.Typically, a H 2 WO 4 solution was prepared by dissolving 1.25 g of H 2 WO 4 into 10 mL of 30 wt H 2 O 2 , which was used for the seed layer deposition and hydrothermal treatment.The seed layer was deposited onto the fluorine-doped stannic oxide (FTO) substrate by spin coating technique, followed by heating at 500 C for 2 h.WO 3 nanosheets were synthesized through a hydrothermal process.Briefly, the seeded FTO substrate, immersed into a mixed solution containing H 2 WO 4 solution, HCl (6 mol/L) and acetonitrile, was put into a Teflon-lined autoclave at 180 C for 6 h.Afterward, the as-prepared sample was washed and annealed at 500 C. Cu 2 O composition was deposited on the surface of WO 3 nanoflakes in a standard three-electrode system including a platinum counter electrode and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode 22.In the typical experiment, the deposition was proceed under A0.4 V voltage for 2 s in 0.5 M cupric acetate aqueous solution.After 150 cycling reduction deposition, the obtained composite, denoted as WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150, was washed by deionized water. The crystal sturcture of the obtained samples were studied by Xray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical X 0 pert PRO).The morphologies and distribution of elements of the obtained samples were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Nova NanoSEM 450) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G 2 F20 S-TWIN).The oxidation states were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250XI).The optical properties of the obtained samples were obtained on a UVeVis spectrometer (Cary 5000). The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction test in H 2 O vapor was measured in a reactor with a top quartz window under A 300 W Xenon arc lamp (PLS-HXF 300, Beijing China Education Au-light Co. Ltd.) with a UV cutoff filter (l 400 nm).The about 85 mg catalyst was placed on a 2.0 A 2.0 cm 2 glass sheet inside the stainless steel cylindrical vessel reactor.Firstly, the reaction setup should be washed by the high purity CO 2 gas (99.999) for more 5 times.The mixture compressed gas, as reactant gas, was generated by the high purity CO 2 through a water bubbler.The gaseous products were got after visible-light illumination, which was then quantifiably identified using an off-line GC-7890II gas chromatograph with both a FID and a TCD using TDX-01 and Porapak-Q columns.In cycling, the used sample was refreshed by water washing and vacuum drying, and then photocatalytic activity was reassessed.The isotopelabelled experiments were performed using 13 CO 2 instead of 12 CO 2 , and the products were analyzed using GC-MS (7890 A and 5975C, Agilent).I-t curves of the obtained samples were conducted using a CHI 660 E electrochemical workstation in a three-electrode system at test voltage of 0 V(vs.Ag/AgCl) 21.The morphology and structure of the prepared samples was investigated using the TEM and SEM measurement.As shown in Fig. 2a, the nanosheet structure was presented in WO 3 sample.With electroreduction time increasing, the cubic Cu 2 O was gradually generated in composites, which formed the 2D/3D WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojunction.The excess Cu 2 O octahedron was coated on the WO 3 sheet surface in WO 3 /Cu 2 O-250 sample, which could hinder the contact between reactant and WO 3 and then weaken the photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction.For further explore the constitution of WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojunction, the TEM of the WO 3 / Cu 2 O-150, as the typical sample, was showed in Fig. 2e andf.The 2D/3D structure was clearly discovered in composites.According to the EDX mapping of designated area, Cu element appeared not only on the Cu 2 O octahedron but also on the WO 3 sheet surface.In HRTEM image, the clear lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.246 and 0.366 nm were corresponding to the (1 1 1) facet of cubic Cu 2 O and the (2 0 1) facet of hexagonal WO 3 , respectively.Additionally, the 0 1A1 zone axis of Cu 2 O was got from the discovered (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) planes in the simulated FFT pattern 12.The highlighted spots were well indexed to the two compositions of Cu 2 O and WO 3 , which further demonstrates their amalgamation at the interfaces.The TEM and the assigned FFT images of WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojunction revealed both hexagonal WO 3 and cubic Cu 2 O phase to appear and be fused at the interfaces.The results may provide some insights into how the heterojunction facilitate interfacial electron transfer and separation and accordingly, promoted the photocatalytic activity.

reaction medium.source: The photoreduction CO 2 activities of the composite samples were studied in the presence of water vapor.
reaction medium.context: The 3D/2D architecture of Cu 2 O octahedrons/WO 3 nanoflake were built on the substrate surface of fluorine-doped stannic oxide.The composite photocatalyst was composed by Cubic phase Cu 2 O/hexagonal phase WO 3 .The photoreduction CO 2 activities of the composite samples were studied in the presence of water vapor.The yields and selection of CO and CH 4 products were changed with deposited Cu 2 O.With the present of Cu 2 O octahedrons on the WO 3 flake, the CH 4 product appeared and the maximal CO and CH 4 yields could attain 7.04 and 8.42 mmol after 24 h of visible-light irradiation.The photostability and photoactivity of Cu 2 O for CO 2 reduction were enhanced by the building of the WO 3 / Cu 2 O heterojuntion.The Type II band alignment for WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojuntion was characterized by UV eVis reflectance and value-band X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy and the Z-scheme mechanism of photoinduced electron-hole was further proposed.This study could offer a new clue for designing Cu 2 Obased heterojunction photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction.

reaction medium.source: According to 13 C labelled isotropic experiment (Fig. S3), the CO and CH 4 products were generated from CO 2 gas reactant in this study.
reaction medium.context: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement of the asprepared samples were conducted to investigate the chemical composition.Fig. 3a showed the Cu 2p spectra of Cu 2 O and WO 3 / Cu 2 O-150 composite, the peaks at 932.4 and 952.2 eV were corresponding to the Cu(I) characteristic peaks 23.Yet, the Cu(II) peak was discovered at at 933.6 eV, which may be due to the oxidation of Cu(I) surface in air.Moreover, the weak and broad satellite peaks around 943.0 eV also appeared 24,25.The binding energies of W4f and Cu2p in pure materials slightly shifted as compared with those in WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150, suggesting a chemical interaction between Cu 2 O and WO 3 26. The optical properties of the as-prepared samples were The photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction using the asprepared samples was investigated under visible-light illumination.The results of control experiments confirmed that no product for CO 2 reduction was detected in the absence of either irradiation or photocatalyst and the photocatalytic activity was never discovered using the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O photocatalysts.WO 3 and Cu 2 O exhibited no or negligible activities for CO 2 reduction, which were mainly attributed to the weak electron reduction ability of WO 3 and rapid recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs in Cu 2 O, respectively.As shown in Fig. 5, the WO 3 / Cu 2 O composite samples all achieved the conversion from CO 2 to value-added products and variety kinds of products was found and included the H 2 , O 2 , CO and CH 4 molecules, which was the reason that water-splitting reaction competed with the CO 2 reduction.According to 13 C labelled isotropic experiment (Fig. S3), the CO and CH 4 products were generated from CO 2 gas reactant in this study.With the Cu 2 O content of composites increasing, the yields of CO and CH 4 products were gradually promoted and the H 2 yield decreased and the percentage of CH 4 yield in catalytic productions also increased (Table S1).The CO, CH 4 Apart from the composition of photocatalyst, the photocatalytic activity was usually influenced on the external conditions, such as the catalytic temperature, total pressure, molar ratio between CO 2 and H 2 O 2,3,30.The results about influence of reaction temperature on the photocatalytic activity were showed in Fig. S4.The photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction was not observably sensitive to the catalytic temperature from 5 C to 60 C. The temperature was hence set to 40 C in this experiment.Fig. 6 showed CO, CH 4 and O 2 yields of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with different molar ratio between CO 2 and H 2 O in the constant total pressure of 0.05 MPa for the optimized catalyst after 7 h irradiation.The CH 4 yield increases and the CO yield never exhibited the distinct change with CO 2 /H 2 O molar ratio increasing.But decrease beyond 0.025 ratio, all products yields showed the evident decrease, which may be explained by the fact that the H 2 O molecules are readily accessible to the catalyst surface with hydroxyl 28.However, too much H 2 O molecules may retard the redox reaction occurring at the surface of the catalyst.The influence of the photocatalytic activity on the catalytic pressure was investigated. Under optimized catalytic conduction, the photocatalytic activity of WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 sample for CO 2 reduction was studied under visible-light illumination.As shown in Fig. 7, all product yields exhibited the escalation, prolonging the illumination time.Only small quantity of H 2 , as reduced production of water splitting, could be discovered after 12 h irradiation, which implied that the WO 3 / Cu 2 O sample has the property of the selected catalysis.The yields of CO, CH 4 , H 2 and O 2 products could attain 7.04, 8.42, 0.80 and 16.27 mmol after 24 h visible-light illumination.As shown in Fig. S5, the experimental yield of O 2 was lower than the theoretical value, and the difference between them increased with prolonging illumination time.It was possible that Cu(I) oxidation consumed the photoinduced holes and H 2 O 2 molecules were generated 28,31. In the practical applications of the long-term use, the reproducibility and durability of photocatalyst never be ignored.In the cycling tests (Fig. 8), the representative WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 photocatalyst was recycled for the four times.In 4 cycling, the CO, CH 4 , H 2 and O 2 yields for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction still reached 4.76, 7.07, 0.40 and 11.84 mmol, respectively.It was revealed that the catalyst could maintain considerable activity.The XRD patterns and XPS spectra, which showed no apparent deterioration as compared to the fresh catalyst, supplied a powerful support for its stability (Figs.S6 andS7). Photocatalytic mechanism of the WO 3 /Cu 2 O samples for CO 2 reduction was studied, according to the experimental results.In this study, the Cu 2 O phase was deposited on the surface of WO 3 , and then the contact between the two phases would form a p-n junction.Under light illumination, the electrons of each semiconductor component in composites could be induced to CB and the holes were accordingly formed in VB.The photoinduced electron-hole separation process in heterojuntion can be schematically depicted in Fig. 9a andb.Since the products of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction never was discovered using the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O sample, the reduction capacity of electrons in the CB of WO 3 would not realize the transform from CO 2 to CO and CH 4 .Based on the band energy alignment of heterojunction, the CB potential of WO 3 (0.06 V vs. NHE) was distinctly more positive than the standard redox potential E (CO2/CO) (A0.53 V vs. NHE) and E (CO2/ CH4) (A0.24 V vs. NHE) and hence, the electron in CB of WO 3 could not reduce CO 2 to CO or CH 4 in thermodynamics 1,2.The similar results was showed that the capacity of hole in the VB of Cu 2 O can not be able to oxidize water 2.According to the enhanced photocatalytic activity, the separation mode of photogenerated electron-hole maybe be followed by the Z-scheme mechanism (Fig. 9b).If so, the photoinduced electrons transfer directly from the CB of WO 3 to the VB of Cu 2 O and recombine with the holes.Hence, the abundant electrons was separated and accumulated in CB of Cu 2 O and the cumulative holes would stay at VB of WO 3 .Based on the band structure of WO 3 and Cu 2 O, the accumulated electron and hole would exhibit the strong reducing and oxidizing ability, which could accomplish CO 2 reduction and H 2 O oxidation, respectively.Hence, the WO 3 /Cu 2 O system may be a type of direct Z-scheme photocatalyst under our experimental conditions. In order to gain more demonstration for the separation of photoinduced electron-hole, transient photocurrent responses of pure and composite samples were recorded in on-off irradiation cycles.Fig. 10 presented the I-t curves for the WO 3 , pure Cu 2 O and WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150 samples.The photocurrent response of the WO 3 / Cu 2 O-150 composites can fast increase under each irradiation and quickly decrease in the dark, which was in accordance with an observation for Cu 2 O sample.Moreover, the photocurrent of the composite was least 2.5 times higher than that of pure sample, which indicated that the heterojuntion in composite brought the enhancement of electron-hole separation efficiency and the reduction of recombination rate 29,32. Based on the above analyses, it was clear that the WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites were typical direct Z-scheme photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction under visible-light irradiation.Nevertheless, the exact mechanism of CO 2 photoreduction was still not clear due to many questions to be unraveled, including the exact reaction pathway, the effects of the reaction conditions, as well as the selectivity of the entire process.Therefore, more experiments should be further made to understand the underlying mechanism of the activity and selectivity of the CO 2 photoreduction.

reaction medium.source: The mechanism of the improved photocatalytic activity was proposed and the photoreduction of CO 2 to CO and CH 4 in mixture atmosphere of CO 2 and water vapor was inferred.
reaction medium.context: A series of WO 3 /Cu 2 O photocatalysts were synthesized by a solvothermal-electrodeposition method.With the Cu 2 O content increasing, the WO 3 /Cu 2 O composite with 2D/3D morphology was formed and brought the enhanced photocatalytic performance for CO 2 reduction under visible light.The CO, CH 4 and H 2 yields for CO 2 reduction under water vapor could attain 7.04, 8.42 and 0.80 mmol after 24 h irradiation using the 2D/3D WO 3 /Cu 2 O photocatalyst.Besides, the effect of light intensity, water pressure and temperature on the photocatalytic activity was also investigated.The photocatalytic activity was not sensitive to the temperature in the experimental range.The mechanism of the improved photocatalytic activity was proposed and the photoreduction of CO 2 to CO and CH 4 in mixture atmosphere of CO 2 and water vapor was inferred.The enhanced photoactivity of WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites was ascribed to the efficient separation of the photoinduced electronhole pairs induced by Z-scheme transfer.In summary, the present research was expected to be useful in developing Z-scheme photocatalysts and provide some meaningful information for deep understanding how the photogenerated electrons transfer across the solid-solid contact interface. Structure, morphology and compositon XRD characterization was performed to investigate the crystal structure of single-component Cu 2 O and WO 3 samples and WO 3 / Cu 2 O composites with different deposition times.As shown in Fig. 1, the diffraction peaks at 36.4 and 42.3 were assigned to the (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) facets of cubic Cu 2 O (JCPDS No. 01-078-2076), and the peak intensities of Cu 2 O increased gradually with the extension of electro-deposition time.It indicated that the (1 1 1) facets of higher activity over cubic Cu 2 O was exhibited in the as-prepared WO 3 /Cu 2 O composite, leading to the enhanced performance for CO 2 reduction 11.Besides the peaks originated from Cu 2 O and FTO substrate, all the other diffraction peaks obtained from WO 3 /Cu 2 O were well indexed to hexagonal WO 3 (JCPDS No. 00-033-1387).The results indicated that Cu 2 O was successfully electrodeposited onto WO 3 platform, confirming the formation of WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites. Fig. 1.XRD patterns of the Cu 2 O, h-WO 3 and WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites. calculated by DRS measurement (Fig.4).The light-absorption edge of pure WO 3 samples could reach about 440 nm and the absorbinglight capacity was increased in the range of 500e800 nm.It was the reason that the surface defect of WO 3 sample was existed.The Cu 2 O and WO 3 /Cu 2 O composites exhibited the strong absorption in visible light range.The composites were possible to become the visible-light-driven photocatalyst.The band gaps (E g ) of the obtained photocatalysts were determined by the plots of (ahn) n versus band energy(Fig.S1).The value of n equals to 0.5 and 2 for WO 3 with an indirect band transition and Cu 2 O with a direct band transition, respectively10,27.The calculated E g values for WO 3 and Cu 2 O were 2.83 and 2.05 eV, agreeing well with the literature reports.Additionally, the VB-XPS spectra of the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O samples were presented in Fig.S2.The valance band maximums (E VB ) of WO 3 and Cu 2 O were measured to be located at 2.89 and 0.91 eV, respectively.Combining with the E g value, the condition band maximums (E CBM ) of WO 3 could be calculated to be 0.06 eV, while the E CB of Cu 2 O could reach A1.14 eV, agreeing with the previously reported values28,29.Hence, a type II (staggered) band alignment band structure of the WO 3 /Cu 2 O composite photocatalyst was successfully formed. and O 2 yields could reach 3.84, 2.22 and 6.11 mmol, respectively.Yet, the overmuch Cu 2 O brought the decline of CO 2 reduction yield.It was the reason that the exposed surface of WO 3 drop with the loaded Cu 2 O raise, leading to the decline for active site of H 2 O oxidation.The WO 3 / Cu 2 O heterojunction could accomplish the photocatalysis for CO 2 reduction and H 2 O oxidation. reactor type.source: The about 85 mg catalyst was placed on a 2.0 A 2.0 cm 2 glass sheet inside the stainless steel cylindrical vessel reactor.
reactor type.context: Hexagonal WO 3 nanosheets were synthesized according to our previous study 21.Typically, a H 2 WO 4 solution was prepared by dissolving 1.25 g of H 2 WO 4 into 10 mL of 30 wt H 2 O 2 , which was used for the seed layer deposition and hydrothermal treatment.The seed layer was deposited onto the fluorine-doped stannic oxide (FTO) substrate by spin coating technique, followed by heating at 500 C for 2 h.WO 3 nanosheets were synthesized through a hydrothermal process.Briefly, the seeded FTO substrate, immersed into a mixed solution containing H 2 WO 4 solution, HCl (6 mol/L) and acetonitrile, was put into a Teflon-lined autoclave at 180 C for 6 h.Afterward, the as-prepared sample was washed and annealed at 500 C. Cu 2 O composition was deposited on the surface of WO 3 nanoflakes in a standard three-electrode system including a platinum counter electrode and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode 22.In the typical experiment, the deposition was proceed under A0.4 V voltage for 2 s in 0.5 M cupric acetate aqueous solution.After 150 cycling reduction deposition, the obtained composite, denoted as WO 3 /Cu 2 O-150, was washed by deionized water. The crystal sturcture of the obtained samples were studied by Xray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical X 0 pert PRO).The morphologies and distribution of elements of the obtained samples were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Nova NanoSEM 450) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G 2 F20 S-TWIN).The oxidation states were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250XI).The optical properties of the obtained samples were obtained on a UVeVis spectrometer (Cary 5000). The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction test in H 2 O vapor was measured in a reactor with a top quartz window under A 300 W Xenon arc lamp (PLS-HXF 300, Beijing China Education Au-light Co. Ltd.) with a UV cutoff filter (l 400 nm).The about 85 mg catalyst was placed on a 2.0 A 2.0 cm 2 glass sheet inside the stainless steel cylindrical vessel reactor.Firstly, the reaction setup should be washed by the high purity CO 2 gas (99.999) for more 5 times.The mixture compressed gas, as reactant gas, was generated by the high purity CO 2 through a water bubbler.The gaseous products were got after visible-light illumination, which was then quantifiably identified using an off-line GC-7890II gas chromatograph with both a FID and a TCD using TDX-01 and Porapak-Q columns.In cycling, the used sample was refreshed by water washing and vacuum drying, and then photocatalytic activity was reassessed.The isotopelabelled experiments were performed using 13 CO 2 instead of 12 CO 2 , and the products were analyzed using GC-MS (7890 A and 5975C, Agilent).I-t curves of the obtained samples were conducted using a CHI 660 E electrochemical workstation in a three-electrode system at test voltage of 0 V(vs.Ag/AgCl) 21.The morphology and structure of the prepared samples was investigated using the TEM and SEM measurement.As shown in Fig. 2a, the nanosheet structure was presented in WO 3 sample.With electroreduction time increasing, the cubic Cu 2 O was gradually generated in composites, which formed the 2D/3D WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojunction.The excess Cu 2 O octahedron was coated on the WO 3 sheet surface in WO 3 /Cu 2 O-250 sample, which could hinder the contact between reactant and WO 3 and then weaken the photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction.For further explore the constitution of WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojunction, the TEM of the WO 3 / Cu 2 O-150, as the typical sample, was showed in Fig. 2e andf.The 2D/3D structure was clearly discovered in composites.According to the EDX mapping of designated area, Cu element appeared not only on the Cu 2 O octahedron but also on the WO 3 sheet surface.In HRTEM image, the clear lattice fringes with d spacing of 0.246 and 0.366 nm were corresponding to the (1 1 1) facet of cubic Cu 2 O and the (2 0 1) facet of hexagonal WO 3 , respectively.Additionally, the 0 1A1 zone axis of Cu 2 O was got from the discovered (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) planes in the simulated FFT pattern 12.The highlighted spots were well indexed to the two compositions of Cu 2 O and WO 3 , which further demonstrates their amalgamation at the interfaces.The TEM and the assigned FFT images of WO 3 /Cu 2 O heterojunction revealed both hexagonal WO 3 and cubic Cu 2 O phase to appear and be fused at the interfaces.The results may provide some insights into how the heterojunction facilitate interfacial electron transfer and separation and accordingly, promoted the photocatalytic activity.
